words.meaning: To search widely for food or provisions.
examples: The squirrels foraged for nuts in the park.
The villagers had to forage for food after the storm destroyed their crops.

words.meaning: To politely or patiently restrain an impulse to do something; refrain.
examples: I had to forbear from shouting at him.
Please forbear from talking during the performance.

words.meaning: Patient self-control; restraint and tolerance.
examples: She showed great forbearance in dealing with the difficult child.
He acted with forbearance, despite being provoked.

words.meaning: A shallow place in a river or stream allowing one to walk or drive across.
examples: They had to cross the river at a shallow ford.
The old bridge was washed away, so they had to use the ford.

words.meaning: A feeling that something bad will happen; fearful apprehension.
examples: She had a sense of foreboding that the trip would not go well.
The dark clouds were a foreboding sign of the coming storm.

words.meaning: The process of taking possession of a mortgaged property as a result of the mortgagor's failure to keep up mortgage payments.
examples: The family lost their home to foreclosure.
The bank initiated foreclosure proceedings against the homeowner.

words.meaning: The part of a view that is nearest to the observer, especially in a picture or photograph.
examples: The flowers in the foreground of the painting are beautifully detailed.
The issue of climate change has been brought to the foreground of public attention.

words.meaning: Able to be foreseen or predicted.
examples: The company will continue to grow for the foreseeable future.
It is foreseeable that the new technology will have a major impact on our lives.

words.meaning: To be a warning or indication of (a future event).
examples: The dark clouds foreshadowed the coming storm.
The author uses the opening scene to foreshadow the tragic ending.

words.meaning: To prevent or obstruct (an anticipated event or action) by taking action ahead of time.
examples: He tried to forestall any objections by addressing them in his opening statement.
The government took measures to forestall an economic crisis.

words.meaning: To lose or be deprived of (property or a right or privilege) as a penalty for wrongdoing.
examples: If you cancel your ticket, you will forfeit your deposit.
The team had to forfeit the game because they did not have enough players.

words.meaning: To make or shape (a metal object) by heating it in a fire or furnace and beating or hammering it.
examples: The blacksmith forged a beautiful sword.
They forged a strong friendship that lasted a lifetime.

words.meaning: The action of forging or producing a copy of a document, signature, banknote, or work of art.
examples: He was arrested for forgery.
The painting was a clever forgery that fooled even the experts.

words.meaning: Pitifully sad and abandoned or lonely.
examples: The forlorn puppy was left alone in the rain.
She had a forlorn expression on her face.

words.meaning: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable.
examples: The team faced a formidable opponent in the championship game.
She has a formidable reputation as a tough negotiator.

words.meaning: To abandon (someone or something).
examples: He would never forsake his family.
She forsook her old habits and started a new life.

words.meaning: To agree to give up or do without (something).
examples: He forswore his allegiance to the king.
She forswore her old life of luxury and became a nun.

words.meaning: A thing at which someone excels.
examples: Singing is her forte.
He is a great cook, but baking is not his forte.

words.meaning: About to happen or appear.
examples: The forthcoming elections are expected to be close.
She was not very forthcoming with information.

words.meaning: (Of a person or their manner or speech) direct and outspoken; straightforward and honest.
examples: She is a forthright person who is not afraid to speak her mind.
He gave a forthright answer to the difficult question.

words.meaning: (Especially in official use) immediately; without delay.
examples: The court ordered him to pay the fine forthwith.
You are to report to the principal's office forthwith.

words.meaning: To strengthen (a place) with defensive works so as to protect it against attack.
examples: The city was fortified with high walls and a deep moat.
He fortified himself with a good breakfast before the long hike.

words.meaning: Courage in pain or adversity.
examples: She showed great fortitude in the face of her illness.
He endured the ordeal with great fortitude.

words.meaning: Happening by accident or chance rather than design.
examples: It was a fortuitous meeting that led to a lifelong friendship.
The fortuitous discovery of the new drug saved many lives.

words.meaning: A short sleep, especially during the day.
examples: I'm just going to have forty winks before we go out.
He felt much better after a quick forty winks.

words.meaning: To encourage or promote the development of (something, typically something regarded as good).
examples: The teacher's goal is to foster a love of learning in her students.
The government is trying to foster economic growth.

words.meaning: (Of a ship) to fill with water and sink.
examples: The ship foundered in the storm.
The company foundered after a series of bad investments.

words.meaning: A noisy disturbance or quarrel.
examples: The police were called to break up a fracas outside the bar.
A fracas erupted between the two teams.

words.meaning: (Typically of children) irritable and quarrelsome.
examples: The fractious child was always getting into trouble.
The fractious group of politicians could not agree on anything.

words.meaning: (Of a person) weak and delicate.
examples: She was a frail old woman who needed help with her daily activities.
The frail bridge was not safe to cross.

words.meaning: The condition of being weak and delicate.
examples: Despite her frailty, she had a strong will to live.
The frailty of the old man was a cause for concern.

words.meaning: To associate or form a friendship with someone, especially when one is not supposed to.
examples: The soldiers were forbidden to fraternize with the local population.
He was accused of fraternizing with the enemy.

words.meaning: Wrongful or criminal deception intended to result in financial or personal gain.
examples: He was arrested for credit card fraud.
The company was accused of committing a massive fraud.

words.meaning: (Of a situation or course of action) filled with or destined to result in (something undesirable).
examples: The journey was fraught with danger.
The negotiations were fraught with tension.

words.meaning: (Of a fabric, rope, or cord) to unravel or become worn at the edge, typically through constant rubbing.
examples: The old rope began to fray.
Her nerves were frayed after the long and stressful day.

words.meaning: Fast and energetic in a rather wild and uncontrolled way.
examples: The city has a frenetic pace of life.
There was a frenetic burst of activity before the deadline.

words.meaning: A state or period of uncontrolled excitement or wild behavior.
examples: The crowd was in a frenzy of excitement.
The sharks were in a feeding frenzy.

words.meaning: A painting done rapidly in watercolor on wet plaster on a wall or ceiling, so that the colors penetrate the plaster and become fixed as it dries.
examples: The church was decorated with beautiful frescoes.
Michelangelo's frescoes in the Sistine Chapel are world-famous.

words.meaning: To be constantly or visibly worried or anxious.
examples: Don't fret, everything will be alright.
She was fretting about her upcoming exam.

words.meaning: Feeling or expressing distress or irritation.
examples: The baby was fretful and wouldn't sleep.
He had a fretful and anxious expression.

words.meaning: A broad horizontal band of sculpted or painted decoration, especially on a wall near the ceiling.
examples: The temple was decorated with a beautiful marble frieze.
The frieze depicted scenes from Greek mythology.

words.meaning: The outer, marginal, or extreme part of an area, group, or sphere of activity.
examples: He lived on the fringe of society.
The festival attracts people from the fringe of the music scene.

words.meaning: Not having any serious purpose or value.
examples: She spent her money on frivolous things.
The lawsuit was dismissed as being frivolous.

words.meaning: From one place to another in a forced and hurried way.
examples: He was driven from pillar to post, looking for a job.
The refugees were moved from pillar to post.

words.meaning: (Of a person) difficult to deal with; contrary.
examples: The froward child refused to obey his parents.
He had a froward and stubborn personality.

words.meaning: To furrow one's brow in an expression of disapproval, displeasure, or concentration.
examples: She frowned when she saw the mess.
He frowned in concentration as he tried to solve the puzzle.

words.meaning: Sparing or economical with regard to money or food.
examples: She is a frugal person who saves her money carefully.
He lived a frugal and simple life.

words.meaning: The quality of being economical with money or food; thriftiness.
examples: She was known for her frugality and simple lifestyle.
In times of hardship, frugality is a virtue.

words.meaning: Producing good results; productive.
examples: They had a fruitful discussion about the future of the company.
The research proved to be very fruitful.

words.meaning: The realization or fulfillment of a plan or project.
examples: After years of hard work, his plans finally came to fruition.
The project reached fruition last year.

words.meaning: Failing to achieve the desired results; unproductive or useless.
examples: His efforts to find a job were fruitless.
The search for the missing plane proved to be fruitless.

words.meaning: To prevent (a plan or attempted action) from progressing, succeeding, or being fulfilled.
examples: The bad weather frustrated their plans for a picnic.
He was frustrated by his lack of progress.

words.meaning: To present or deal with (something) in a vague, noncommittal, or inadequate way, especially so as to conceal the truth or mislead.
examples: He tried to fudge the numbers on his expense report.
The politician fudged the issue when asked about his controversial past.

words.meaning: The point on which a lever rests or is supported and on which it pivots.
examples: The fulcrum is the pivot point of a seesaw.
He was the fulcrum of the team, and everything revolved around him.

words.meaning: To express vehement protest.
examples: He would often fulminate against the evils of modern society.
The politician fulminated against the new tax increase.

words.meaning: Complimentary or flattering to an excessive degree.
examples: She was embarrassed by his fulsome praise.
The book received fulsome reviews from the critics.

words.meaning: Having the mournful, somber character appropriate to a funeral.
examples: The room had a funereal atmosphere.
He spoke in a funereal tone of voice.

words.meaning: (Of goods contracted for without an individual specimen being specified) able to replace or be replaced by another identical item; mutually interchangeable.
examples: Money is fungible, so it doesn't matter which dollar bill you use.
Commodities like oil and wheat are fungible.

words.meaning: An outbreak of public anger or excitement.
examples: The new policy caused a furor among the students.
The book created a furor when it was first published.

words.meaning: Attempting to avoid notice or attention, typically because of guilt or a belief that discovery would lead to trouble; secretive.
examples: He cast a furtive glance in her direction.
The spy made a furtive exchange of documents.
